Dear Tia M. Cobb:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iv)Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a youth’s
background or appearance or mental state. Yelling, threats,
ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff and youth name call Youth A.
Investigation I spoke to Administrator 1 on 4/17/24, allegations were
discussed. No additional information was provided.
I spoke to DHHS Worker 1 on 4/17/24; allegations and scheduling
were discussed.
I spoke to Complainant 1 on 4/17/24; allegations were discussed.
No new information was provided.
I left a voicemail to Worker 1 on 4/17/24. A return phone call did
not occur.
The following interviews were completed with DHHS Worker 1 at
the facility on 4/22/24:
Youth A:
Youth A reported that Youth B and Youth C call him names often
and Staff 2 told him to “shut the fuck up.” Youth A did not report
any other comments made by Staff 2.
Youth B and Youth C:
Youth B and Youth C both reported they are in the same pod as
Youth A. Youth A will disrespect them by starting problems and
2

name calling. Both youths reported they will name call back. Both
reported staff present will redirect the youth and sometimes they
will listen to staff and sometimes they will not. Both reported they
have never heard staff call names to Youth A.
Youth D:
Youth D refused to answer questions.
Staff 1, Staff 2. Staff 3, Staff 4, and Staff 5 all reported that
Youth A argues back and forth with other youth in the units. All
staff reported Youth A name calls others and the other youth will
name call back to Youth A. All reported they redirect the youth
when these exchanges occur.
Staff 2 reported he has said “shut the fuck up” to Youth A, a few
times. Staff 2 reported it is okay to talk to Youth A in this manner
due to Youth A’s upbringing and/or culture therefore, Youth A
understands this language. Staff 2 reported Youth A speaks in a
“street fashion” therefore that is the way he can be talked to.
Documents Reviewed:
• I reviewed the Behavior Management policy, which
prohibits verbal abuse as a form of intervention.
• Staff 2 does not have discipline in his file.
Analysis The agency is in violation with this rule. Staff 2 admitted to using
derogatory language towards Youth A.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Emergency restraint
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4160
Section (1) The use of emergency restraint as a lifesaving response for a
Description youth will be limited to:
(a) An emergency response to protect the youth or others from
an unanticipated or severely aggressive behavior that places the
youth or others at serious threat of violence or injury if no
immediate intervention occurs.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff are not restraining youth to keep Youth A safe. Youth A is
being “stomped” on and “jumped” by other youth.
3

Investigation
I spoke to Complainant 1 on 4/17/24 via telephone. Complainant
1 reported Youth A switched units on 4/9/24. Complainant 1
reported a week before this move, he was stomped on by his
peers and another peer threw a chair at him. Complainant 1
reported Youth A has stated to her that he is afraid for his safety.
Complainant 1 reported he has bruises on his arms, legs, back,
and chest. Complainant 1 reported she saw bruises near his arms
where the short sleeves end and small bruising on his legs,
unspecified area. Complainant 1 reported Youth A would not allow
her to see his chest and back areas. Complainant 1 reported
Youth A does have a history of self-harm.
I spoke to Administrator 1 on 4/17/24 via telephone.
Administrator 1 reported she is unaware of anyone hurting Youth
A. Administrator 1 reported Youth A started fights in his first unit
and then was moved to his current unit. Administrator 1 reported
Youth A will not allow anyone to look at the bruises he may have.
(Youth A was currently with the nurse and refusing to allow her to
see any bruises.) Administrator 1 reported Youth A states that
“everyone is out to get him.” Administrator 1 reported she has
looked at the camera footage she has and cannot see anyone
hurting Youth A. Administrator 1 reported Youth A will not tell her
how he received the bruises.
The following interviews were completed face to face at the facility
on 4/22/24 with DHHS Worker 1:
Therapist 1:
Therapist 1 reported Youth A struggles to accept responsibility for
his behaviors. Therapist 1 reported Youth A demonstrates
paranoia and is always preoccupied with whether or not others are
watching him. Therapist 1 reported Youth A has extensive mental
health history, including auditory hallucinations. Youth A also has
a history of self-harming behaviors. Therapist 1 reported he was
moved from his initial pod on 4/8/24. Therapist 1 reported Youth A
was involved in an incident on 4/5/24 where both him and another
youth (unknown) argued and then attempted to assault each
other. Therapist 1 reported staff intervened, but no one was
restrained.
Youth A:
Youth A reported he was punched on 4/16/24, 4/17/24, and
4/19/24. Youth A reported one time Youth B, Youth C, and Youth
D assaulted him together. Youth A reported they grabbed him
4

after showers and started punching him. Youth A reported during
another occurrence, Youth D punched him during lunch time.
Youth A reported on 4/19/24, youth were “horseplaying” and
“youth beat him up.” Youth A was unsure which youth. Youth A
was distracted during interview and continued to look around.
Youth A would not show any bruises to this consultant, nor would
he say where he received them.
**It is to be noted this intake occurred on 4/17/24. Two of these
situations occurred after the intake, whereas only the 4/16/24
incident occurred before.
On 5/3/24, the following interviews were conducted face to
face at the facility with DHHS Worker 1:
Youth B:
Youth B reported he is in Youth A’s current unit. Youth A had
argued with him and then threw a chair at him. Youth B did not
know the date. Youth B reported staff intervened and verbally
redirected them. Youth B reported staff opened Youth A’s
bedroom door so that Youth A can go into it and Youth A went into
it to get away from the situation. Youth B reported he does not
know the staff’s names.
Youth C:
Youth C reported he is currently in Youth A’s unit. Youth A argues
with others and then becomes upset when other youth want to hit
him. Youth C reported staff “protect” him. Youth C reported staff
will step in and redirect them verbally and move Youth A to a safe
area which is usually Youth A’s room. Youth A did not mention
specifically which staff.
Youth D:
Youth D refused to answer questions.
Nurse 1:
Nurse 1 reported she has seen Youth A three times up to present
date and each time Youth A gives her multiple stories to what is
happening to him. Youth A reported to her that he has bruises on
his left and right forearm, and she has seen them. Nurse 1
described them as dark bruising and not yellow. Nurse 1 reported
Youth A did not mention any other bruising on his body.
5

Staff 1:
Staff 1 reported Youth A antagonizes other youth. Staff 1 reported
as an example to this, Youth A had spoken disrespectfully about
Youth C’s deceased grandmother. Staff 1 reported Youth C was
upset and wanted to assault him, but staff were able to verbally
deescalate this situation. On another occasion, Youth A was
separated from Youth C after he had provoked Youth C. Staff 1
reported once Youth A begins to act aggressive, he struggles to
deescalate even if the other youth are not engaged. Staff 1
reported they have never had to restrain Youth A. Staff 1 reported
they (unknown other staff) got in between Youth A and another
peer and Youth A stated “everyone was beating him up” although
this never happened. Staff 1 did not know the dates of these
situations.
Staff 2:
Staff 2 reported the youth “horseplay” and then it escalates into
fighting. Staff 2 reported Youth A does get involved in the
horseplay. Staff 2 reported he allows the horseplay because they
are boys, although he acknowledged it ends with the youth
fighting. Staff 2 reported “horseplay” is defined as “punching and
hitting the body, wrestling and rough housing.” Staff 2 reported he
lets the horseplay continue until it gets “serious.” Serious was
defined as “getting into each other’s faces, name calling, and
pushing.” Staff 2 reported when it gets serious, he redirects them,
guards the youth, and separates them. Staff 2 reported Youth A
will go into his room when he is escalated. Staff 2 reports Youth A
always thinks others are talking about him and states he is going
to make complaints to get out of the facility. Staff 2 did not have
dates of incidents and did not remember any incidents where
Youth A was physically assaulted outside of the generic
horseplaying.
Staff 3:
Staff 3 reported she was specifically there for an incident that
occurred on 4/5/24. Staff 3 reported Youth A was using profanity,
and she was unsure why. Staff 3 reported she did not know him
that well due to him being new, but she recognized that Youth A
would lose focus and become angry very quickly. Staff 3 reported
no one was hurt during this incident and Youth A was placed in his
room to deescalate. Staff 3 could not remember who else was
involved. Staff 3 reported this was the only incident she was
involved in. Staff 3 reported she has seen him hitting his head up
against the wall in his bedroom before as a self-harming behavior.
6

Staff 4:
Staff 4 reported Youth A is paranoid and is always thinking others
are after him. Staff 4 reported she was involved in an incident
where Youth A was interacting with other youth in a negative
manner. Staff 4 reported she does not remember the date, but
Youth A stated a comment towards another youth, and she had to
run over to him and separate the youths.
Staff 5:
Staff 5 reported he only remembers one incident where Youth A
was hit by another youth. Staff 5 reported other youth were
attempting to hit Youth A and Staff 5 blocked them from hitting
him. Staff 5 reported they called for backup and extra staff came
into the unit.
Document and Video Review:
There are no incident reports or video showing Youth A being
assaulted by Youth B, Youth C and Youth D together. Due to the
lack of specific time frames, all incident reports were reviewed for
Youth A. Youth A entered the facility on 3/21/24. By 4/8/24, he
was moved to his current unit.
• Incident Report: 4/5/24: Youth A threw a chair at another
youth. The other youth hit Youth A. Staff 4 was present and
separated the youth. Video observation confirms the details
in the incident report.
• Incident Report: 4/17/24: Youth A verbally disputing
with Youth C. Staff 1 attempted to verbally deescalate,
which was unsuccessful and Youth C hit Youth A in the
face, both youths exchanged punches, and both were
separated by staff. Video observation confirms the details
in the incident report. Video observation also showed other
youth attempting to help and separate Youth A and Youth
C. Staff were present, engaged, and separated youth.
Youth A was escorted into his bedroom and the situation
was deescalated.
• Incident Report 4/19/24: Youth D and Youth A were
verbally arguing. Youth D assaulted Youth A. Staff 5
stepped in and separated them. Video confirms the details
in the incident report.
Analysis The agency is compliant with this rule. Based on video
observation, Youth A is not being stomped on or jumped by other
7

youth. Staff are intervening in each incident noted above.
Although the staff are not restraining the youth, they are
deescalating the situation by removing Youth A from the room or
physically separating the youth with their own bodies.
Technical Assistance: On each video observation it was seen
that multiple activities were occurring in the unit. The youth were
engaged in eating lunch, watching television, listening to music,
and playing board games. It would benefit the agency to have a
more structured environment, focusing on one activity at a time.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
Violation Additional Findings
Type
Allegation Staff 2 allows youth to “horseplay,” punch and hit each other,
wrestle, and roughhouse.
Investigation The following interviews were completed at the facility on 5/3/24
with DHHS Worker 1:
Staff 2:
Staff 2 reported the youth “horseplay” and then this escalates into
fighting. Staff 2 reported Youth A does get involved in the
horseplay. Staff 2 reported he allows the horseplay because they
are boys, although he acknowledged this ends in fighting. Staff 2
reported “horseplay” is defined as “punching and hitting the body,
wrestling and rough housing.” Staff 2 reported he lets the
horseplay continue until it gets “serious.” Serious was defined as
“getting into each other’s faces, name calling, and pushing.” Staff
2 reported when it gets serious, he redirects them, guards the
youth, and separates them. Staff 2 did not call a group attention.
Staff 3, Staff 4, and Staff 5 all reported they do not allow
“horseplay” in the unit. All reported this is not allowed and are to
stop this once it starts. All reported to redirect this behavior or call
8

a “group attention,” which is part of their behavior management
procedures.
Therapist 1 provided the Group Attention Policy via email on
5/6/24. Therapist 1 reported they do not have a policy specific to
horseplaying, but “rather methods to intervene when youth are
horseplaying.”
Documents Reviewed:
Group Assistance Problem-Solving Meeting Policy:
…is a meeting that is requested by a staff or resident to address
the negative behavior of another resident…
Analysis The agency is in violation of this rule. Staff 2 admitted to allowing
youth in the program to punch, hit, wrestle, and rough house with
each other. Staff 2 reported this was “horseplay.” Staff 3, 4, and 5
all reported horseplay is not allowed. When this negative behavior
occurs, a Group Attention (GA) is to be called to stop the
behavior. The Group Assistance Problem-Solving Meeting Policy
requires staff to call a “GA” when youth are demonstrating
negative behaviors.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
